Issue #24 // April 23, 2021

Software Infrastructure 2.0: A Wishlist
// erikbern.com
Erik Bernhardson makes 5-10 year prediction about software infrastructure and creates a wishlist to make it more enjoyable and productive.
Having On-call Nightmares? Runbooks can Help you Wake Up.
// blameless.com
A good runbook takes time and iterations for it to be maximally informative. With each outage, runbooks can be tuned and hardened to be more helpful for the people acking the alert.
The Software Engineer’s Complete Guide to Code Quality
// betterprogramming.pub
Know the importance of code standards, reviews, documentation, and more. Tools, frameworks, and style guides are used to take a lot of the guesswork out of decision making, freeing developers to focus on more interesting tasks.
Airbnb Deploys 125,000+ Times per Year with Multicluster Kubernetes
// altoros.com
AirBnb has scaled its marketplace in Kubernetes to 7,000+ nodes across 36 clusters. Since the migration to Kubernetes, Airbnb has reached no less than 125,000 production deploys per year.
Software Designers, Not Engineers
// tomasp.net
This fictional interview reveals how very different the world of software is when we think of programmers as software designers rather than as software engineers.
How Do You Track of Releases Micro-Services?
// news.ycombinator.com
A Hacker News discussion on how various teams deal with deploying tons of micro-services.
Tiny Container Challenge
// devopsdirective.com
Sid sets out to build the smallest container image that could that was still able to do something useful. He ends up with a 6kB containerized HTTP server.
Why I Distrust Google Cloud More Than AWS or Azure
// iasylum.net
The clock is ticking for Google Cloud. The Google unit, which sells computing services to big companies, is under pressure from top management to pass Amazon or Microsoft-currently first and second, respectively, in cloud market share-or risk losing funding.
Why You Need a Platform Team for Kubernetes
// polarsquad.com
Kubernetes moves fast; when it’s a critical part of your infrastructure, there’s a host of things you need to look out for to maintain a healthy cluster. More often than not, it’s wise to have a dedicated team to run Kubernetes.
Platform Engineering vs. Site Reliability Engineering
// effx.com
The lines between these functions can be often blurred or they can operate interchangeably. This article describes how you'd see these two teams get introduced and eventually evolve as an organization's engineering team were to scale.
